properties.address: Bombay Talkies Compound, Himanshu Roy Amarsi Road, Somwari Bazar, Malad West, Mumbai, Maharashtra 400064
properties.description:
Bombay Talkies was among the largest pre-WW II sound studios in India and introduced some of the major stars and directors of post-independence Hindi cinema (Dev Anand, Raj Kapoor, Ashok Kumar, Dilip Kumar). Founded by Himansu Rai and Devika Rani after their return from Europe in 1934, it was the only major studio established as a full-fledged corporate body with a board of directors that included prominent business leaders of Bombay. Recalling the early history of Bombay Talkies, the Urdu writer Hasan Manto Himansu Rai as an extremely hard working, disciplined idealist. “He laid down the foundations of the Bombay Talkies in such a manner that it would appear as an ideal production house. This is why he selected for his company a spot that was far away from Bombay city.”
Quoted in: Manto, S. Meena Bazaar, Rajkamal Prakashan, New Delhi, 2001, 30.

properties.address: 5th Floor, Jewel Building, Maharshi Karve Rd, Opera House, Girgaon, Mumbai, Maharashtra 400004
properties.description: Achhut Kanya premiered at the Roxy Cinema in 1936, boasting a glittering cosmopolitan audience. Poster of Achhut Kanya, picturing Devika Rani.

properties.address: Raj Kamal Marg, MINT Colony, Parel, Mumbai, Maharashtra 400012
properties.description:
Wadia Movietone was established in 1933 by J.B.H. Wadia and Homi Wadia with the help of Parsi mercantile capital. Most of their films were intentionally addressed to the C-grade exhibition sector and tried to recapture J.B.H. Wadia’s early cinephiliac fascination with Hollywood serials and Westerns. The studio was located at Lovji Castle in the upper-class neighborhood Parel, an ancestral estate of the Wadias, who were master-ship builders to the East India Company and then the Government of India. With shipping still in his blood, J.B.H Wadia wrote in an autobiographical essay that he used to advertise his films as “a cargo load of rich variety brought into port by the Wadia ship.”
Quoted in: “Those Were The Days” in Ramachandran, T. M., Burra, R., Chandran, M., and Indian Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences. (1981). Fifty Years of Indian Talkies, 1931-1981: A Commemorative Volume. Bombay: Indian Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences.

properties.address: MS Ali Road, Near Express Rest, Grant Road East, Bharat Nagar, Kamathipura, Mumbai, Maharashtra 400007
properties.description: Hunterwali premiered at the Super Cinema in 1935. The film ran to packed houses for more than 25 weeks and became the major money spinner of the year. A still of “Fearless Nadia” in Hunterwali.

In the 1930s, cinema and film were all-apparent in the topography of Bombay. In this context, cinema posters and stills were an attractive way of advertising films. Indeed, by giving the audience an idea of what to expect inside the hall, posters and stills provided a powerful incentive to give in to the cinema habit. J. Stenson, the Entertainment Duty Tax officer of the Report of the Indian Cinematograph Committee stated: “I have noticed many times that boys of 8 or 9 years old loaf about the cinema halls at odd hours of the night. I have personally observed many times that young boys instead of being in bed are always loafing round the theatres looking at the posters and so on, at a time when they should be in bed.”
Quoted in: India. (1928). Report of the Indian Cinematograph Committee: 1927-1928, Evidence. Calcutta: Govt. of India Central Publication Branch, 40.

properties.address: A/9 Bharat Nagar, MS Ali Road, Grant Road East, Bharat Nagar, Grant Rd, Mumbai, Maharashtra 400007, India
properties.description:
The very publicity program for Hunterwali describes the film as the following: “Hunterwali!: What visions does that film stir up! It is the story of a brave Indian girl who sacrificed royal luxury to the cause of her people and country,” but it is also “a spectacular thriller, the first of its kind in India.” A viewer of Fearless Nadia remembers: “The single most memorable sound of my childhood is the clarion call of Hey-y-y-y-y as Fearless Nadia, regal on her horse, her hand raised defiantly in the air, rode down upon the bad guys. To us school kids Fearless Nadia meant courage, strength, idealism.”
A viewer of Fearless Nadia remembers: “We were forced to keep ourselves under control everywhere: at work, in the family, faced with out superiors, on the street, there was nowhere we could give full rein to our emotions – apart from the cinema. There we could shout and laugh and cry without it being invasive or embarrassing. Everyone did it. And that is the reason too why the Nadia films were so popular because no other film managed to draw us in as much. Come the end of the film we were completely drained and exhausted. But at the same time there was a magnificent relief, a catharsis.”

properties.address: Panna Arcade, Supari, Charni Road, Tata Road No 1, Opera House, Girgaon, Mumbai, Maharashtra 400004, India
properties.description:
Acchut Kanya was highly acclaimed for its serious theme of the problems of the caste system and untouchability. At the same time, due to the reputation Devika Rani and Himansu Rai already had, the film’s premiere boasted an impressive cosmopolitan audeince. As the Times of India from August 26, 1936, declared: even the congress president saw Bombay Talkies’ Achhut Kanya. Nehru reportedly even wrote a fan letter to Devika Rani after seeing her in Achhut Kanya. Achhut Kanya’s most famous sound was “Main Ban Ki Chidiya Banke” (insert sound file). Music and songs play an important role in the dream world conjured by Hindi films. In the 1930s, it was quite common for a Bombay feature film to have up to 40 songs.
Q. Hyder remembers Devika Rani and Achhut Kanya in her autobiographical essay, Memories of an Indian Childhood. Here, Devika Rani is remembered for her family background, Achhut Kanya being one of the few films Hyder’s parents allowed her to watch on the grounds that India had “at last entered the era of cultural revolution” because Gurudev Tagore’s own niece had become a cinema actress.
